Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Rare-Earth-Free All Ferrous Nanomagnets Towards High Energy Density
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Summary:
Increases in energy density of permanent magnets are currently achieved through the incorporation of rare earth elements into the metal alloys. Replacing non-sustainable and strategically undesirable rare-earth elements is one of the most critical challenges. This CAREER project investigates rare-earth-free alloy nanomagnets for high energy density, based exclusively on traditional elements Fe, Co and Ni. The success of this project removes environmentally non-sustainable rare-earth implementations, promotes emerging green energy technologies, and establishes U.S. leadership in rare-earth-free magnet development. The project integrates energy-critical nanometal research with education and outreach at the exciting interface of materials science and sustainable nanotechnologies, which encourage underrepresented minorities to pursue unique cutting-edge magnetic material training, and fosters the public awareness of transformative magnetic nanotechnology in sustainability and green energy. Similar opportunities are designed for high-school science teachers, in part to help them be better equipped for advising high school students about science-based careers.

Technical Summary:
This CAREER project aims to address a key challenge of sustainable rare-earth-free metallic nanostructures: the energy density of all ferrous alloy nanomagnets is dictated chiefly by the precise control of their metastable tetragonal structural properties and dopant distribution on the atomic scale. The research objective of this project is to understand basic parameters that govern synthesis, doping and self-assembly of tetragonal ferrous alloys and to explore their unique exchange-coupling properties for high energy density nanomagnets. The project is comprised of the following interrelated activities: (1) synthesis of tetragonal iron-cobalt nanostructures using phase transformations, (2) exploring the doping and order-disorder transition of single domain iron-nickel using chemical transformation and interfacial diffusion alloying, and (3) exchange-coupling of magnetically hard and soft ferrous nanocomposites to achieve high energy density rare-earth-free nanomagnets. Beyond the local and regional educational benefits, the research entails a major benefit to society in that successful results could lead to the revolution of rare-earth-free permanent magnets and contribute to green energy technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Buffalo
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project is to investigate high energy product rare-earth (RE)-free magnetic metal nanoalloys, where the energy product is largely dictated by their tetragonal structure induced magnetocrystalline anisotropy. The precise control of the dimension, chemical composition and geometry for the magnetic nanocrystals enables the correlation among structure, processing and magnetic properties of these earth abundant nanoalloys. The motivation behind of this project is driven by the fact of today’s advanced permanent magnets are predominantly based on rare-earth elements, such as NdFeB or SmCo5 based supermagnets. The energy product increases of permanent magnets were achieved through the incorporation of rare earths into the metal alloys. In light of unsustainable RE supply and ever-growing demand for RE alternatives in energy-critical technologies, there is a strong motivation to develop RE-free magnetic materials, where replacing non-sustainable and strategically undesirable RE elements is one of the most critical challenges.

 

Covering the entire life of the award, we have been developing strategies to control magnetocrystalline anisotropy of magnetic metal alloy nanostructures through three different strategies: 1) phase transformation from the cubic disordered phase to the tetragonal ordered phase; 2) shape anisotropy through anisotropic magnetic nanostructure formation; and 3) a low-temperature and universal nanomanufacturing approach for the synthetic control of magnetic alloys. All strategies exhibit the structure-controlled magnetic performance for enhanced energy product of magnetic nanoalloys.  There are several research efforts in the PI’s group to pursue the RE-free magnetic nanoalloys, including FeCo, FeNi and FePd, etc. The rational design and growth of magnetic nanocomposites comprised of two or more materials has also been considered a promising strategy for energy product challenges. In this context, magnetic core-shell nanocomposites by coupling magnetically hard and soft phases can simultaneously achieve high magnetocrystalline anisotropy and saturation magnetization. These core-shell architectures can efficiently tune magnetic properties (such as the thermal stability of magnetization and coercivity) via control of the core-shell parameters, including the shape, size, and chemical composition. There is an immediate need for a simple, scalable and reliable synthesis method for high-performance metallic core-shell nanocomposites with the coupling interactions at the core and the shell interfaces. 

 

The success of this project leads to a breakthrough for the development of RE-free high energy product permanent magnet. The project demonstrated the rational control over their stoichiometry, structure, and magnetocrystalline anisotropy in nanostructured metal nanoparticles. The specific achievements include the following: 1) the new growth methodology for nanometal formation in the molecular scale precision with the size, stoichiometry and morphology control; 2) the core-shell structure concept to incorporate magnetically soft and hard magnet together with the exchange coupling for high energy product; 3) the relationships among the structure, assembly processing and magnetic properties of nanometal alloys to guide new magnetic metal material design and growth. The research progress made from this project has been added into the magnetic examples for teaching and educational resources. In addition, this project has been actively engaging under-represented undergraduate researchers. These students have distinguished themselves in a number of ways by co-authoring on peer-reviewed journal articles.


Last Modified: 06/01/2021
Modified by: Shenqiang Ren
